segments.text: Mr. Taylor, can you tell me your rank and organization when you were in Vietnam?
In 1966, I was a warrant officer, helicopter pilot, the 119th Assault Helicopter Company at Pleiku, Vietnam.
My first tour ended in November 1967.
My second tour, I was a chief warrant officer with the 101st Airborne Division at Camp Eagle, Hue, Vietnam.
from October 69 through October 70.
In 1971, I was on temporary duty at Fan Rang for a few days.
I left the service as a Chief Warrant Officer.
Okay, as a helicopter pilot, what was your single most important contribution in the American Forces, in your opinion?
I believe it was the ability to provide mobility
to the ground forces.
It enabled us to eliminate a lot of the mistakes of the French at the military level, though I think at the political level we made a lot of the same mistakes.
Individually, it allowed us to develop tactics and lessons learned
which has enabled us currently to counter a lot of our potential adversaries, conventional weapons threats, armor especially.
I can't say individually where I had any great contributions other than learning the tactics, becoming an instructor, and then passing those on to men between tours, and I felt that that
probably saved a lot of lives because the military, as usual, is slow to respond.
So a lot of us knew that the school solution was not the right answer.
And as a result, we taught the young men the lessons that we had learned in Vietnam and better prepared the second generation of pilots that had to go over there.
I believe the mobility.
So do you think there would have been a drastic difference in the way the war was fought without the use of the helicopter?
Yes, and it might have been better because during the Vietnam War, terrain, seizing and holding terrain, was not as important to us as it had been in earlier wars.
Such as Korea?
Well, such as Korea, such as the French Indochina War in World War II,
That was one of our blessings, but it may have been a curse because we didn't secure, quotes, military lines of communication.
And as a result, a lot of gaps were left that allowed the guerrilla army and later the North Vietnamese army using guerrilla tactics to pretty well move at will, especially at night.
It also left a lot of villages susceptible
to the influence of those armies.

The local cadres were decimated in Tet, yet this absence of our controlling completely the lines of communications and holding terrain allowed the infiltration of North Vietnamese army units to completely maintain their domination in certain areas.
over the local population.
Now, the blessings I'd have it was by our being able to move, not be restricted to roads, rail, etc.
It held the casualties down considerably.
I'm convinced that if it hadn't been for the helicopter, one of two things would have happened.
We would have left very early,
or we would have escalated the war to a greater conflict, quite possibly even tried tactical nukes, because in those days the thinking was that they were a useful weapon.
I don't believe we would have politically withstood something along the lines of the French casualty rate in their war in Indochina.
I don't believe that we would have politically withstood a Dien Bien Phu.
And given the climate prior to 1969, I think that a major defeat for American forces in Vietnam would have led to an American outcry to escalate, not as later.
This slow bleeding process and the news bringing that into the rooms every night led to an anti-war feeling.
I think that the shock of a major defeat
would have been much like the shock of Pearl Harbor or a major battle in Europe.
I see.
So the use of the helicopter, its importance is a lot more
I think it basically allowed the Vietnam War to go on for 10 years.
It's a lot more important than it appeared to be.
It was more than just a piece of machinery.
Yes, it was not an ambulance.
In the early days, we learned to fight with it and turned it into a very, very good fighting platform, a good transportation platform, and a good civil platform.
One of the outgrowths today of that war is the abundance of
helicopter pilots, helicopter-oriented individuals in the American civil community.
And as a result, you've got all of the life flights, the care flights, the ability to exploit the oil offshore, things that were not possible in the mid-'60s.
These are a direct result of the war.
The bad thing is is that transportation ability allowed us to avoid a major defeat because we could extract our forces very quickly.
or rapidly reinforce our forces very quickly.
As a result, we very seldom suffered a defeat above the company level.
As a matter of fact, we did not suffer a single military defeat at the battle or campaign level during the war.
That's all because of the helicopter.
The French lost regiments.
Between Mangyang Pass and Pleiku, where I was stationed, the 2nd Korea Regiment, after the French withdrawal had begun,
practically decimated in that 20-mile, 25-mile stretch of road.
And then as they tried to retreat south, they were further beat up.
I saw parts of their armored vehicles laying in the jungle when I was over there fighting in 67.
and this had occurred several years before.
They did not have the helicopter to the extent that we did, even though they did originally try to arm it, and they used it for some medical evacuation.
So the Americans protected it basically?
I think that we kept our infantry in Vietnam from 1964, 65, until 1973 at a basic no-win, no-defeat level.
because of the ability of the helicopter to maneuver our troops.
I think had we not had the helicopter, the decision would have had to been made very early, win it or lose it.
It allowed our political people to maintain a, quote, acceptable casualty level over a long period of time without committing the national will to either victory or to cut their losses.
So I believe that that small group of chopper pilots were...
were the reasons that we held out so long, reasons our casualties were so low.
And for your information, we've gathered data since to kind of prove the theory of that war.
Now, what we did, though, was one in five of us died on the first tour.
And one in three of us died if we served two tours.
That's a hell of a price to pay among the best
young men the country has, because the military pilot requirements require the absolute brightest and best physical people.
Anything else?
Were there any policies or rules of any sort that you felt restricted you, made you incapable?
Very restricted policies.
We understood them, but they were very restrictive.
In 1967, at least in the two core area, and this was general policy of the
17th Aviation Group and I believe the 1st Aviation Brigade.
It was definite policy of my battalion, the 52nd.
We could not return fire when we were being fired on if we were in certain areas.
Now we did have those areas that were known as free fire zones.
Those are areas that the Vietnamese authorities and the military had made a sweep, had removed the people.
or at least those that wanted to come out.
And activity in that area was considered completely enemy activity.
And the area around Pleiku, a lot of it is jungle.
Now, Pleiku sits on a high plateau, plain-type area, but it ends in mountains all around it.
And those vary from 5 or 10 miles.
For instance, the Yadrang Valley is just about a 10- to 15-minute flight
southwest from Camp Holloway at Pleiku.
That's how close we were to a battle you may be familiar with.
It was the first big battle involving American forces.
Doctoe was 25 minutes north.
The area called Dragon Mountain, we called it Titty Mountain.
The newspapers named it Dragon Mountain, and the 4th Division named it Dragon Mountain because they didn't like our name for it.
Uh, the, these are, these are battles, uh, cheerio.
Uh, the, the, these valleys are, are just minutes away from camp Holloway play coup.
And as a result, our battalion thought in all of those engagements, but there are a lot of villages around there.
Many of these villages are more friendly and for the most part, very, very friendly to the American forces.

I went down one time with absolutely nothing on board because toward the end of my tour I was doing a test flight and had gone out to do a visual reconnaissance for the battalion intelligence and had an engine failure.
I went down by this mountain yard village.
The deadliest thing I had on board was a P-38 can opener.
I mean, these people could have killed us.
They didn't.
They came out and were real friendly.
Next day I dropped them some parachute claw.
The business that every village and everybody considered the people on the ground as hostile was not true, at least among the helicopter pilots.
But we did get shot at from the ground.
And we knew there were a lot of areas and a lot of villages that were hostile to us to some degree.
But what would happen is the North Vietnamese, and it was primarily NVA in my area, would move in near a village
and shoot at us and want us to strafe, want us to fire back because they knew that we would, our weapon systems weren't precise enough to pick out a single individual.
We would pick out a single area with rockets or a single area with machine guns.
And so they knew that we would create casualties.
As a result, our commanders issued orders and very strictly enforced those orders.
We had one guy
strafe a Buddhist temple once because he had been fired up.
We'd been getting fired up by this, around this temple for days.
Every time we would fly past, I'd been shot at there.
Old Jim got hit one day.
His aircraft got hit.
He loaded, or unloaded on him.
And the commander got very upset.
Jim's attitude was, sir, when they shooted me that often, shame on them.
He put a stop to it.
Nothing happened, but as a general rule, especially at night, getting fired on from known village areas, we didn't return fire, and any number of pilots had that.
Can I give you an instance?
Let's see what that question is.
Just an example.
Can I give an example?
when I felt powerless to do anything.
I don't think you'll like this answer because it's not politically a Vietnam answer per se.

1975, when I saw those tanks rolling down in the news film, rolling down from the north and watching the south collapse, watching the leadership in the United States fail to do what they promised two years earlier, which was to commit
U.S. bombers to interdict any major raids to the south.
And a few B-52 raids would have sent the message to the north.
They would have said, oh boy, turned around and gone back.
It took that kind of action to make them release our prisoners.
That same kind of action would have let them know that we were serious.
The French-trained officer corps at the very top
of the South Vietnamese Army was as corrupt as the French Army was in 1940 because the same colonial officers basically still ran the damn thing and trained these people.
Most of the officers, the high-ranking officers, were French trained.
Now, at the colonel level and lieutenant colonel level and below, American trained officers were beginning to move up.
At the major level and below, almost every one of them was American trained.

And what had happened there is friends of mine in the Vietnamese services woke up, they were captains and majors, and they said, I woke up in Da Nang one morning and I was the highest ranking officer there.
The colonels and the generals had left.
They'd gotten the word.
So, my most helpless feeling
was to sit there and watch that country fall.

And the words of our president and our country committed to two years earlier, albeit we were involved in a Watergate-type situation, it was pretty well over with, and we had an interim government, if you will, under Nixon's predecessor.
There was no willingness to keep that commitment.
to watch these people fleeing south by the thousands, jamming the roads, not just the military, but thousands of civilians moving south.
These people didn't want the communists.
They saw the communists at Hue in 1968.
They saw the communists, for the most part, in the north after the French.
But to sit there and watch them come south,
And no, there's not a damn thing you can do about it.
There's not a thing your government's going to do about it.
I'm not saying we should have recommitted the draftees.
By now, we had a ground army in the Arvins that were trained.
They had some good leaders and they had some bad leaders.
But an infantryman is as good as his leadership.
Anyone who ever tells you Vietnamese can't fight doesn't understand
leadership.
The North Vietnamese and the South Vietnamese are the same people.
That was going to be my next question.
What you thought about the Army?
Well, I'll get to that in just a minute.
I want to finish my helpless feet.
To watch this come south and then to take a look at people you've known and to realize what they're getting into, to see the South fall and to know that leaders such as the infantry colonel
who realized all was lost.

He could have very easily done like a lot of them did and got on a plane, but he felt like someone had to uphold the honor and he went out in front of the statue of the unknown soldier and put a bullet in his head.
To see dedicated people like that betrayed by a group of what I call political opportunists who started

Using the anti-war sentiment in the late 60s to gain political power by the mid-70s, to watch that occur here reminded me a lot of what I've read about the Weimar Republic in Germany toward the end and afterward of the First World War.
It was a very helpful speech and one I'll never forget, one I don't intend to ever let my sons participate in.
You know my sons and you know the way they've been
been taught, you know, that they take nobody's word for anything.
They go get original references where possible, read them and examine them.
Could not be another generation if I could help.
Let me be involved.
And the colonels and generals of today are the lieutenants and captains of yesterday.
And you can see the distrust they had, even with the crappy little job they were given.
Take out this little
Banana Republic.
They went down and they did it.
They did it very quickly with a minimum expenditure of life.
They allowed no reporters and no political interference once the decision was done until the job was over.
I think that is another tragedy of Vietnam.
It put a distrust between our military leadership and some of the political and media types.
I think we'll suffer from that until the Vietnam generation of officers are retired, and maybe longer.
That was helpless.
That was not in combat.
Helpless feelings in combat is when you're sitting there and mortar shells and rockets are raining down and you don't have an airplane under your butt so you can move and maneuver.
I feel totally helpless.
Different people that served in Vietnam have different things to say about Arvin.
Some say they were dedicated.
Some say they weren't.
I have had a lot of people talk about the Arvin.
And when you start asking them where they were and what they were doing, you find out they were with American units engaged in areas where there were no Arvin.
Or they were looking at the Arvin militia.
Arvin was just like us.
He had good leaders.
He had bad leaders.
He had his callies, and he had his heroes.
And at the soldier level, the Arvins were draftees for the most part.
Some were led by competent NCOs, and some were led by absolute disasters, just as we had in our Army and the draftee army.
Some of their officers would not have made a squad leader, and some were absolutely brilliant.
In general, I would say that when the Arvin was properly led by competent officers that he had faith in, he was as tough as any soldier over there.
I'll give you an example of that.
The Arvin Marines.
When the South fell, the Arvin, I say Arvin in general, meaning all military, the Arvin Marine Brigade and its commander went to the bush en masse.
and refused to surrender.
It took them until 1980 for the Reds to dig all those boys out of the trees.

My Vietnamese friends in this country have shown me videotapes of convoys of Soviet and American trucks moving down roads in the Delta and little guys in black pajamas coming out of those woods and just decimating that convoy.
And those little guys in black pajamas this time
were pro-American.
And these enlisted men knew that very little would happen to them.
The MCOs knew that they might get their hands slapped.
The officers knew that they would probably be shot or imprisoned.
But nobody forced these young men to go with their officers.
You know, the war was over, guys.
Come on in.
Yet they went.
The point is, in general, when he was properly led, he was a good soldier.
When he was properly led by North Vietnamese cadre, he was a damn good soldier.
He fought tenaciously.
We fought Vietnamese.
So to paint the Arvin as a coward who ran and hid, it's not true.
When he was properly led, properly trained, he was good.
The problem was the training was sporadic, and a lot of the officers were corrupt.
A lot of the officers were corrupt.
The percentages were not as high as the American newspapers would have you believe.
I've met very many officers out of England, and you knew they weren't corrupt.
And yet, then you meet some young field-grade major over here who had a political rank and maybe worked in some district, and you couldn't get the sorry bastard out of his bunker.
He would send his people out.
Well, I wouldn't follow a leader like that either.
And I wouldn't risk my life for a leader like that.
Tell me about some of your relationships with the Vietnamese people there.
In the area that I was in Pleiku, the only relationship I had with the local Vietnamese, as opposed to the Montagnard, were the people who were on post.
And in general, I felt very sorry for them because of the circumstances.
Having served my first military tour to Korea as a younger man, I had developed an affinity for picking up some languages and an empathy for the Oriental people, an admiration.
I mean, people who can take a light bulb that you throw away and make a watch crystal out of it, who can take a gun barrel that you think is burned out
put one man on it, polish it up, and have it working.
I mean, these people are pretty darn good.
I like the Mountain Yard.
I really like it.
I guess it was because of the tribal primitiveness of them.
I mean, I felt they were kind of unspoiled, and I kind of watched them over the course of the war become spoiled.
And I thought about the American Indian and how close they resembled what I had read about the American Indian.
And I liked them.
I admired those that came here.
I tried to help.
And I get along very well in the community of the Vietnamese today because of the activities and friendships I made in those days.
Recently, my wife and I were invited to a Vietnamese wedding.
It was from the former Vietnamese Air Force Association.
Us and two others were the only Caucasian couples there out of 200 people.
When the former Vietnamese Air Force went national recently, myself
an Air Force Brigadier and an Air Force Colonel were invited over for the initiation and had some of the former leadership of South Vietnam.
Not that I like them that much at the time and don't respect them today.
With some exceptions I do, but General Key was there.
I didn't particularly care for Key then and I don't like him now.
He was one of those French trained types that I didn't respect, but he was a good fighter.
Nobody ever called him a coward.
General Lone, the guy that put the bullet in the spy's head, I was the guest at his table.
That was on national television with this bullet.
Maybe you'd like to hear the story behind that bullet.
Okay.
I asked General Lone what he would do different.
And he said he would take the film.
And...
As a general officer, General Lone was not political.
It's pretty obvious he wasn't political because he shot the man on national television.

He was not political, but he was very well respected by the South Vietnamese because he was an airborne general and he came up the hard way and made no pretense of anything other than a combat infantryman.
Now, at the time, he was in charge of the Saigon police because it was a military emergency.

This innocent civilian, this guy in civilian clothes that got a bullet in the head, was a North Vietnamese Army lieutenant who had just led a unit that had just slaughtered the family of General Loan's aide.
He had been caught.
He was brought in.
And they said, this is the one.
And as General Loan said, I am a general officer authorized to conduct a summary court
under emergency conditions, and I conducted it.
And he shot the man, and that is why nobody has ever brought that man up on war crafts.
Every military officer in the world knows that an enemy officer in civilian clothes who has just committed an atrocity, I'm not talking about blowing up a military installation.
The man slaughtered a guy's family, for God's sakes.

has the right to execute that individual whether the trial takes three days three years or three minutes is up to the convening officer and that's that general i'm sure that if it hadn't been his aid that the man had shot and the family of his aid that the man had shot then i'm sure the general would quite probably have told him to take him over and use a firing squad
But this was such an atrocity to this general that he personally took his pistol and killed the man.
Kind of the spur of the moment.
Not spur of the moment.
I'm sure he was that angry.
Oh, yeah.
Yeah, it may have been spur of the moment, but he wasn't political.
It was within his right.
He executed a spy.
Now, whether he pulled the trigger himself or had it done by 12 good men tried and true over here is not the point.
He had the authority.
He exercised that authority.
That's why he's never been brought up as a war criminal.
And you've never heard an outcry other than the political press.
There's never been a formal diplomatic or military outcry for that man to be court-martialed.
And he was left in this country.
Getting a little low on tape, we'll turn it over.
Okay, let's just change it up a little bit and talk about chemical weapons.
Okay.
I know you work with chemical weapons now.
I work with Defense Against Chemical Weapons.
Defense Against Chemical Weapons.
Okay.
You know something about them.
Why don't you...
Tell me about some different types of chemicals used in Vietnam and what the purposes were.
Well, we'd first off have to define chemical, but if you consider napalm a chemical, that was used on occasion, used in flamethrowers also.
By the way, the North Vietnamese had good flamethrowers.
They cooked a bunch of villagers just south of my base one time.
They didn't have the planes down there to deliver the napalm, but an individual spraying it kills them just as dead, maybe not as many.
But getting into the chemicals, CS gas mostly, kind of a powerful tear gas.
They used it, we used it.
The other chemical we used was at that time called defoliant, and I heard the term Agent Orange between tours.
First tour when we had it, it was simply called defoliant.
It had an orange thing on top of the barrel, so that's where it got its name.
We weren't trained in its use.
We were told to put it in these tanks and go out and spray it on the trees around the fire bases and clear the fire bases.
Now, the Air Force Ranch Hand Program was clear in the jungle.
We were just clearing 500-meter strips around fire bases with it.
Basically, a mixture of 2,4-D and 2,4-5-T, which is used in our rice country.
2,4-D is used, 2,4-5-T, but they're not used full strength.
The problem is in the manufacture of this agent during the war,
they left out a key quality control step.
As they were running it through, the process dioxin buildup occurs.
And the dioxin could be as small as five parts per billion.
Or in some cases, they've analyzed barrels of it and found it as high.
And this is not generally published, to my knowledge, 168 parts per million.
which means it's extremely toxic.

And because of the shoddy quality control done by the chemical manufacturer and the United States government, we sprayed a poison that had been considered safe when it was used as 2,4-D and 2,4-5-T. Because in the manufacturing process for the government, they left out those quality control steps that allowed the dioxin buildup.
Dioxin is one of the byproducts of this manufacturer, as I understand it.
I'm not completely familiar with that.
But that particular piece was shoddy manufacturing processes.
And as a result, no one really thought it was that harmful.
But one of us always wore a gas mask when we were spraying it, just in case the tank was ruptured and the stuff came around.
And I've seen it come, you know, take the paint off the tail boom of my helicopter.
And I've come back with
My uniform saturated with the stuff because we flew with the doors open and the windows open and stuff like that when we were dropping, so you'd fly back through your own mist a lot of times.
We would empty that same container, put spray in it, DDT, and go spray the troops for mosquito control.
We were our own worst enemies in chemical warfare there because we sprayed our own troops.
We never sprayed Charlie.

Occasionally, if we had any left, we would go out and spray Charlie's rice crop, where the intelligence officer had told us to, but that was about two or three missions, and we found we were getting fired at so bad, and we had slicks at the time, not gunships, we carried these tanks in, that we told the chemical officer and the intelligence officer that if they wanted that damn stuff dropped,
on those farms out there, then they were going to have to provide gunship escort because those farmers didn't want their rice crops to break.
And so we didn't go do that very often after that.
Chemicals, I had several experiences with tear gas, ours and theirs, ours being some of our troops would toss tear gas.
We had tear gas in the perimeter.
Lightning would hit during the monsoon.
and set off several containers of tear gas, or these containers would fire tear gas out.
Those would go off.
Several claymore mines would go off.
Occasionally, a thing called fugas, which is a napalm mixture, would go off.
Now, the other chemical agent that was used was phosphorus, white phosphorus.
Used them as smoke shells to mark artillery rounds.
That's what we used for spotter.
And God help the poor son of a gun that got phosphorus on him.
If our artillery was accurate on him at the first round, then he really got hurt.
As far as this chemical warfare of germ warfare agents, as far as chemical warfare in the terms of poison gases, those were not used, at least not to my knowledge.
And I've never found anyone who knows they were.
That goes back to the Korean War.
when the Chinese sanitary conditions were causing such tremendous losses among their forces.
Their propaganda was, it's not us that's doing it.
It's the germ warfare of the Americans and the chemical warfare of the Americans.
The people who've used chemical warfare, I'm talking about lethal agents, have been the Soviets.
Our army is still to this day not geared to do it.
That's why I'm working to try to build a defense for it.
You don't use the stuff if you can't defend yourself against it, your own stuff.
But the Soviet army has always been able to do that, and all of their surrogate states have, and as a result, around the world.
Since 1963 in Yemen, with the Soviet surrogates of the day, Egypt, they've used lethal agents, primarily mustard and carbon.
That's blister gas and nerve gas.
So that's the sum total of my chemical warfare.
In Vietnam, we used tear gas a lot.
We would use tear gas to run them out of caves.
We would use tear gas to flush them out of villages and bunkers near villages.
And to me, using tear gas on a village to flush people out and try to catch them is a lot more humane than going in and putting napalm on the whole damn village.
Because sooner or later, you've got to make a decision of how many more men are going to die because of that machine gun nest.
When that decision's made, you're going to take out that machine gun nest or you're going to quit that pipe, one of the two.
Were the benefits of using chemicals that great in Vietnam?
I mean, looking back on it now compared to the past.
Looking back on it, I ended up with soft tissue tumor, as you well know, and I laid a lot of it back to the dioxin.
But I think
We started using it, well, the high command, I'm sure, started using defoliants to defoliate problem areas that they would take tremendous casualties in.
The Iron Triangle was practically all defoliated.
That was the Ranch Hand Project.
They went in after that and used their own plows to knock down the sticks because these were hiding places for the enemy units that were threatening Saigon.
In our area where it was used, it was used to clear...
areas around the fire bases.
And this wasn't used around every fire base, depending on how long they planned to stay there.
Around Chia Rio, for instance, is where I used a lot of it to clear two or three places around Chia Rio.
And it was very effective.
It meant that that unit had a clear field where they could have some hope of seeing.
You have to understand the North Vietnamese soldier was a very good jungle fighter.
By that I mean he was a master at camouflage.
He lived in that damn jungle and our people didn't.
And he could move through that jungle very quietly, very patiently when he wanted to.
And so with our policy of building these little fire bases, miniature forts,
The perimeter of that fort quotes or the outpost 50 meters away was the outer line of defense.
And if that outer line of defense, if you've only cleaned out that one area and your outer line of defense now stops at brush and scrub 20 and 30 feet high.
You've left an area there where you have an entire regiment crawl upon you before you even know they're there.
So we cleared these fields of fire, these areas around the bases.
And so I think it was very good.
I blame our own people, whether they are engineers in the chemical companies or whether they are purchasing people in the US government for allowing the dioxin buildup.
They never allowed that combination to go
to the commercial farmer without checking that step in the quality control process yet, just because they were going to drop it on the enemy in the jungle.
They never made that check.
And the dioxin buildup is causing casualties to this day in some people, I believe.
OK.
I'm going to switch the tone again.
What do you think of Johnson's?

Johnson's campaign after 64 for 64 we had a saying and we laughed about it in Vietnam you have to understand I was in the military and I voted for Goldwater at that time but the saying was you know if you if you vote for Goldwater you'll be at war in six months and once we got to Vietnam the guy said you know
They told me if I voted for Goldwater, I was going to be at war in six months.
By God, I voted for Goldwater, and here I am.
They were right.
So I didn't like Johnson.
I didn't like Johnson's talking down to the American people when he was addressing them.
I felt Vietnam was necessary in the beginning.
I didn't like the way the war was being conducted.
By that I mean

no wind policy uh the the restrictions on firing i can understand the initial restrictions but the bombing halls the the slow build up build up give them a chance to respond instead of coming in there with a massive uh and i don't mean commit the entire american population but enough firepower in the right places to do the job the damn targets

for the Air Force was being picked in Washington and it was being picked as much on political grounds as military grounds and to risk the lives of all of those hundreds and thousands of young men for political targets, meaning go out and bomb rice paddies instead of bombing the dikes and knocking out their agricultural economy, bombing their ports and closing that off and bringing that war to a halt rather quickly.
They dragged it out because they were, quote, afraid of the Soviet Union might intervene, afraid that China might intervene.
Feathers.
We knew at the time their economies wouldn't stand it.
They had proven to us three years earlier at the Bay of Pig, or correction, at the Cuban crisis.
They didn't want a major war with the United States.
And as long as we didn't invade the North and try to occupy the North, but only prevent the North from taking over the South, it would have been status quo.
Johnson's lack of political will and leadership, I'm convinced, doomed 55,000 Americans to die and close to half a million to be wounded because the war dragged out so long.
People say that it was...
It was Johnson's personal war.
What do you think of that?
Well, it was being directed for the most part.
I think he had delusions of being a Churchill the way he had his, from what I can understand, his bunker set up under the White House there with his little war situation room.
I don't know this.
But when those kind of decisions are made,
And they still commit Americans.
Or we would effectively stop the enemy flow of supplies.
Allow the interdiction.
Stop the flow of supplies.
And then the North would say, we'd like to talk.
We'd stop our bombing.
They'd build up their supplies.
Then they'd go back to fighting.
We'd start bombing again.
We'd like to talk.
About the second time they did that, he should have said, OK, talk.
But he should have kept bombing.
He didn't.
I blame McNamara.
McNamara almost decimated the officer corps of the United States.
The high ranking officers who were good leaders were replaced, forced to resign during the course of that war.
The Westmoreland, I don't have a lot of respect for Westmoreland.
I like the man.
I guess I've heard him speak.
He seemed like a nice individual.
He did not have the military guts to stand up, resign, and go public.
He had the likes of McNamara, who admits he had made his decision in 67 that the war was unwinnable, yet he didn't quit in 67.
He didn't even attempt to win it or to notify the people to back down.
He kept acquiescing.
His lack of political will, Wes Moreland's lack of it, I was very disappointed in that.
Let's flip the tape over here.
